Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	format=flowed

Rob,

The species with many atoms can be handled by hand-editing the cti fi=
le 
produced by ck2cti.  The mechanism you are trying to use has some 
irre=
versible reactions with fractional product stoichiometric 
coefficients.  T=
he ck2cti program will not accept these, but if you can 
convert them into =
cti format in some other way, I believe Cantera will 
accept them.  Cantera=
 internally stores stoichiometric coefficients as 
real numbers, not intege=
rs.  Reactant stoichiometric coefficients must 
be integral, since they are=
 used as reaction orders of elementary 
reactions. But this is not a proble=
m for product stoichiometric 
coefficients for irreversible reactions.  Nev=
ertheless, I don't quite 
know how to think about reactions that produce a =
fraction of an H 
atom...

Dave


Fractional stoichiometries cannot be spec=
ified directly in Cantera, but 
you can achieve the same effect by specifyi=
ng the reaction order in the 
cti file.

On Mar 8, 2005, at 1:02 PM, Trante=
r, Robert Simon wrote:

> =A0
>
> Dr Goodwin,
>
> I am trying to use ck2cti=
 to convert the 1 atm soot model from Howard 
> et al. (http://web.mit.edu/=
anish/www/mitsootmodel1atmsymp2004.mec) 
> from the Chemkin format to cti a=
nd I am encountering a couple of 
> problems. The mechanism includes a numb=
er of species with very large 
> numbers of carbon and hydrogen atoms e.g. =
species BIN7J has C=3D1560 and 
> H=3D479. It appears that in the format us=
ed in the Chemkin style thermo 
> file there is not enough space to define =
the molecular composition and 
> Howard and coworkers have used a modified =
version of CKINTERP to read 
> the composition from some information append=
ed to the first line of 
> the thermo data for each of these large species.=
 Of course this causes 
> a problem when trying to use ck2cti. I have tried=
 just inserting the 
> carbon and hydrogen numbers into the first line in t=
heir normal 
> position but of course that only causes a different error.
>=

> =A0
>
> In addition to the above problem the mechanism also uses fractio=
nal 
> stoichiometires (see last line of attached ck2cti log file) which 
>=
 appear to cause problems for ck2cti.
>
> =A0
>
> Any advice you can give o=
n solving the above problems would be welcome.
>
> =A0
>
> The thermo and t=
ransport files for the soot model can be obtained at
>
> http://web.mit.edu=
/anish/www/tranmitsymp2004.dat
>
> =A0
>
> http://web.mit.edu/anish/www/the=
rmmitsymp2004.dat
>
> =A0
>
> Regards
>
> =A0
>
> Rob Tranter
>

t S. Tranter

Content-Type: text/enriched;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252

Rob, 


The species with many atoms can be handled by hand-editing the cti
=
file produced by ck2cti.  The mechanism you are trying to use has some
irre=
versible reactions with fractional product stoichiometric
coefficients.  Th=
e ck2cti program will not accept these, but if you
can convert them into ct=
i format in some other way, I believe Cantera
will accept them.  Cantera in=
ternally stores stoichiometric
coefficients as real numbers, not integers. =
 Reactant stoichiometric
coefficients must be integral, since they are used=
 as reaction orders
of elementary reactions. But this is not a problem for =
product
stoichiometric coefficients for irreversible reactions.  Neverthele=
ss,
I don't quite know how to think about reactions that produce a
fraction=
 of an H atom...


Dave



Fractional stoichiometries cannot be specified d=
irectly in Cantera,
but you can achieve the same effect by specifying the r=
eaction order
in the cti file.
